intro: Borreria ocymoides f. bisepala, commonly known as the twin-lobed borreria, is a flowering plant belonging to the Rubiaceae family. It is a shrub characterized by its slender, branched stems and opposite, ovate leaves with a slightly hairy surface. The plant produces small, clustered flowers that are typically white or pale pink, with four petals. It is native to tropical regions of Central and South America, where it thrives in humid, shaded environments. This variant is distinguished by its unique floral morphology, featuring two distinct lobes on the petals, which set it apart from other forms of Borreria ocymoides.
